PanaetiuS‚ he says (7), divided the subject of practica] mo·· rality into three headS, consideriug under the first the question whether an action was right3 under the second, whether an action was expedient3 under the third, the conflict between the two· He discussedthe first two points in the three pub· lished books, but left his work -unfinished Many persons think that the omission was intentional, because, from the nature of the case, a conflict between what is right and what is expedient is impossible.

That Panaetius intended to discuss this point (III. 11) can- not be doubted; but whether he was justified in admitting the existence of such a question is a matter on which opinions may differ. Whether, with the Stoics, we hold that virtue is the only good, or, with the Peripatetics, that nothing else is of any weight in comparison with virtue, in neither case can there be any conflict between right and expediency; and, as ’ Panaetius held the Stoic view (12), it would seem that he could not have admitted the possibility of such a conflict. But a completely virtuous action (13) can be performed only by the sapiens ; other men attain only the semblance of such conduct3 and the duties of which we are treating (14) are the media officia, such as are performed by ordinary men.
